metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Afco Private Ltd.

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd., a private limited company, earned total income for the year ending March 31, 1955, computed at Rs. 49,843/- by Income-tax Tribunal.
Company declared dividend of Rs. 11,712/- on July 13, 1955.
Company declared additional dividend of Rs. 5,612/- before close of assessment year 1955-56.
Aggregate dividends distributed were not less than 60% of total income reduced by income-tax and super-tax payable.
Company claimed rebate at one anna in the rupee on amount computed per Schedule I, Part I, Item B read with s.2 of Finance Act 15 of 1955.
Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected claim as s.23A of Income-tax Act applicable to private company.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, reversed ITO and AAC, holding rebate available if conditions in s.23A fulfilled.
Tribunal referred question to High Court of Bombay: Whether assessee entitled to rebate having distributed over 60%? HC answered in affirmative.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the assessee company having distributed dividends of over 60% of total income less income-tax and super-tax is entitled to rebate of 1 anna per rupee on undistributed balance as per proviso to Item B, Part I, 1st Schedule to Finance Act 1955, notwithstanding being a private company to which s.23A could be applicable.

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'company to which provisions of s.23A cannot be made applicable' in Finance Act 1955 describes class of companies against which s.23A order can never be made; private companies excluded as s.23A applicable if dividend conditions not met.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.23A Income-tax Act; Finance Act 1955 Sch I Part I Item B

respondent_arguments.text: Expression 'cannot be made applicable' read with s.23A means rebate available if conditions in s.23A fulfilled i.e., dividends >=60%, even for private companies.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.23A Income-tax Act; Finance Act 1955 Sch I Part I Item B

court_reasoning.text: Expression 'cannot be made applicable' means no order under s.23A justified in circumstances, not that s.23A never applicable to class; applicability depends on ITO order after checking sub-s.(9) exclusion and reasonableness of dividend.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature used 'cannot be made applicable' indicating depends on order, not statutory exclusion.

court_reasoning.text: s.23A enacted to prevent super-tax evasion via companies; rebate inducement for adequate dividends to avoid s.23A rigour.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Private companies competent for s.23A order if conditions met.

court_reasoning.text: Legislative history: Prior Finance Acts conditioned rebate on no s.23A order made, causing delays; 1955 Act simplified to circumstances where order cannot be made, not excluding private companies as class.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Phraseology differs from super-tax rebates explicitly for public companies.

holdings.text: Assessee private company entitled to rebate if dividends distributed such that s.23A order cannot be made in circumstances.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs additional super-tax on undistributed profits if dividends <60%; exclusion for public interest companies; rebate tied to non-applicability.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act 15 of 1955
sections: Schedule I Part I Item B proviso
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes rebate of one anna per rupee for companies where s.23A cannot be made applicable and dividends arrangements met.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Private company not deemed public substantially interested per Explanation 1(b) to s.23A.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds High Court right; assessee Afco Private Ltd. entitled to rebate claimed under Finance Act 1955 as dividends distributed exceeded 60% threshold making s.23A inapplicable in circumstances.
outcome.relief_granted: Rebate of one anna per rupee on undistributed balance allowed.

key_quotes.text: "The Legislature has used the expression cannot be made applicable which clearly means that the applicability of s. 23A depends upon an order to be made by the Income-tax Officer, and not upon any exclusion by the provisions of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In our judgment the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were right in so holding."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms lower courts' view on rebate eligibility.
